pullRequest.body:
This PR adds versions of the maximum modulus principle for functions vanishing at infinity that parallel those we already had for functions over a bounded set. These will have applications in e.g. norm interpolation.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: I had briefly considered doing this, but I couldn't immediately figure out how to deal with point 2. I'll give your suggestion a shot when I get a chance.

I think there's a bit of room for improvement here. Below are some simple code improvements / golfs (`aesop` is great!). However, the more important considerations are the following:

1. You should prove these *before* the bounded versions, and then use the `zero_at_infty` versions to prove the bounded ones. Like so:
```lean
theorem exists_mem_frontier_isMaxOn_norm [FiniteDimensional ℂ E] {f : E → F} {U : Set E}
    (hb : IsBounded U) (hne : U.Nonempty) (hd : DiffContOnCl ℂ f U) :
    ∃ z ∈ frontier U, IsMaxOn (norm ∘ f) (closure U) z := by
  refine exists_mem_frontier_isMaxOn_norm_of_zero_at_infty ?_
    (NormedSpace.unbounded_univ ℂ E <| · ▸ hb) hne hd
  convert tendsto_bot
  rw [Filter.inf_principal_eq_bot]
  exact hb.isCompact_closure.compl_mem_cocompact
```
2. In trying to implement the above suggestion, I realized that the latter 3 of your 4 lemmas have a `[Finite Dimensional ℂ E]` assumption that the bounded ones don't. After a cursory glance, I think it's possible to implement the same technique employed by those (although it may be slightly more work; in particular, I think you need to choose `w ∈ Uᶜ` instead of via `exists_ne`, that way when you restrict to `line_map` the set isn't `univ` because it contains `w`):
```lean
  /- In case of a finite dimensional domain, one can just apply
    `Complex.exists_mem_frontier_isMaxOn_norm`. To make it work in any Banach space, we restrict
    the function to a line first. -/
```
It's also possible I'm missing something because I didn't actually write the proof.

I think there's a bit of room for improvement here. Below are some simple code improvements / golfs (`aesop` is great!). However, the more important considerations are the following:

1. You should prove these *before* the bounded versions, and then use the `zero_at_infty` versions to prove the bounded ones. Like so:
```lean
theorem exists_mem_frontier_isMaxOn_norm [FiniteDimensional ℂ E] {f : E → F} {U : Set E}

    ∃ z ∈ frontier U, IsMaxOn (norm ∘ f) (closure U) z := by
  refine exists_mem_frontier_isMaxOn_norm_of_zero_at_infty ?_
    (NormedSpace.unbounded_univ ℂ E <| · ▸ hb) hne hd
  convert tendsto_bot
  rw [Filter.inf_principal_eq_bot]
  exact hb.isCompact_closure.compl_mem_cocompact
```
2. In trying to implement the above suggestion, I realized that the latter 3 of your 4 lemmas have a `[Finite Dimensional ℂ E]` assumption that the bounded ones don't. After a cursory glance, I think it's possible to implement the same technique employed by those (although it may be slightly more work; in particular, I think you need to choose `w ∈ Uᶜ` instead of via `exists_ne`, that way when you restrict to `line_map` the set isn't `univ` because it contains `w`):
```lean
  /- In case of a finite dimensional domain, one can just apply
    `Complex.exists_mem_frontier_isMaxOn_norm`. To make it work in any Banach space, we restrict
    the function to a line first. -/
```
It's also possible I'm missing something because I didn't actually write the proof.

nit
```suggestion
    (hU : U ≠ univ) (hne : U.Nonempty) (hd : DiffContOnCl ℂ f U) :
    ∃ z ∈ frontier U, IsMaxOn (norm ∘ f) (closure U) z := by
```

```suggestion
      exact ⟨x₀, ⟨Set.mem_of_subset_of_mem subset_closure hx₀, isMaxOn_iff.mpr <| by aesop⟩⟩
```

```suggestion
  rw [closure_eq_interior_union_frontier, mem_union, or_comm] at hwU
  rcases hwU with (hwU | hwU); · exact ⟨w, hwU, hle⟩
```

```suggestion
  rcases exists_mem_frontier_infDist_compl_eq_dist hwU (by aesop) with ⟨z, hzU, hzw⟩
```

```suggestion
    simpa using hf_tendsto.sub hg_tendsto
  exact fun z => norm_le_of_forall_mem_frontier_norm_le_of_zero_at_infty htendsto hU
    (hf.sub hg) fun w hw => by simp [hfg hw]
```

pullRequest.title: feat: maximum modulus principle for functions vanishing at infinity

nodes.body:
I think there's a bit of room for improvement here. Below are some simple code improvements / golfs (`aesop` is great!). However, the more important considerations are the following:

1. You should prove these *before* the bounded versions, and then use the `zero_at_infty` versions to prove the bounded ones. Like so:
```lean
theorem exists_mem_frontier_isMaxOn_norm [FiniteDimensional ℂ E] {f : E → F} {U : Set E}
    (hb : IsBounded U) (hne : U.Nonempty) (hd : DiffContOnCl ℂ f U) :
    ∃ z ∈ frontier U, IsMaxOn (norm ∘ f) (closure U) z := by
  refine exists_mem_frontier_isMaxOn_norm_of_zero_at_infty ?_
    (NormedSpace.unbounded_univ ℂ E <| · ▸ hb) hne hd
  convert tendsto_bot
  rw [Filter.inf_principal_eq_bot]
  exact hb.isCompact_closure.compl_mem_cocompact
```
2. In trying to implement the above suggestion, I realized that the latter 3 of your 4 lemmas have a `[Finite Dimensional ℂ E]` assumption that the bounded ones don't. After a cursory glance, I think it's possible to implement the same technique employed by those (although it may be slightly more work; in particular, I think you need to choose `w ∈ Uᶜ` instead of via `exists_ne`, that way when you restrict to `line_map` the set isn't `univ` because it contains `w`):
```lean
  /- In case of a finite dimensional domain, one can just apply
    `Complex.exists_mem_frontier_isMaxOn_norm`. To make it work in any Banach space, we restrict
    the function to a line first. -/
```
It's also possible I'm missing something because I didn't actually write the proof.
I had briefly considered doing this, but I couldn't immediately figure out how to deal with point 2. I'll give your suggestion a shot when I get a chance.
